history.content:
I took 120 as a first-semester sophomore and it's by far one of the most important classes I've taken. If you're remotely interested in any part of EE, dealing with LTI systems and Fourier/Z/Laplace transforms is fundamental. It's not a particularly intense course in terms of workload - pretty reasonable weekly psets. It may not be the most useful if you're pure CS, but for anyone else it's a useful, interesting, and rewarding class. Feeds really well into 123/128 if you're interested in those.

-------------------------------------------

I took EE 120 as a first-semester junior with Prof. Babak Ayazifar this past semester. I wasn't expecting to find the material that interesting, but Babak did a great job at teaching it and I actually enjoyed the class so much that I signed up to take EE 123 the following semester. (I believe Babak is teaching the class again next semester.) Babak's lectures were almost never boring and he developed every topic very smoothly and carefully, probably because he's taught the class many times.

This class is different from EE 16A and 16B in that it's much more focused around a single progression of topics. The whole class is basically just learning six different transforms one after the other, plus some extra mathematical techniques that can also be viewed as extensions of the transforms. Homeworks were less frequent than 16A and 16B homeworks (we ended up only having 6 over the whole semester) and were also much more straightforward.

I took 120 as a first-semester sophomore and it's by far one of the most important classes I've taken. If you're remotely interested in any part of EE, dealing with LTI systems and Fourier/Z/Laplace transforms is fundamental. It's not a particularly intense course in terms of workload - pretty reasonable weekly psets. It may not be the most useful if you're pure CS, but for anyone else it's a useful, interesting, and rewarding class. Feeds really well into 123/128 if you're interested in those.

children.subject: I agree with the other student response - I definitely found them less intense than 16B problem sets, and they are less frequent. I also second that Babak is a wonderful professor, and made the class that much better!
Is 120 worth anything for generic SWE and/or ML?

As another person who took ee120 with babak, I will say no it is not. Think of the class as "Mathematical Methods for Circuit Design and Signal Processing". There are unfortunately few applications to SWE or ML. However, for anything robotics or controls related, definitely take. For ML, you are better off taking more probability theory and linear algebra. AFAIK, ML doesn't use much in terms of fourier transforms.

Hi Dinesh,

Thanks for your response!  In terms of workload, how would you say the EE120 problem sets compare to EE16B problem sets?

history.content: I'd like to get as much feedback about this class as possible. What do people who have taken this class think about it?
history.subject: EE120
